awd_titl_txt: MRI: Acquisition of an ion chromatograph mass spectrometer for research and education
awd_abstract_narration:
This award is supported by the Major Research Instrumentation (MRI), the Chemistry Research Instrumentation, and the Experimental Program to Stimulate Competitive Research (EPSCoR) programs. Professor Jianye Zhang from Voorhees College and colleagues Omar Bagasra (Claflin University) and Yaoling Long (South Carolina State University) are acquiring an ion-chromatograph mass-spectrometer that serves three Historically Black Colleges and Universities (HBCUs). In general, mass spectrometry (MS) is one of the key analytical methods used to identify and characterize small quantities of chemical species in complex samples. In a typical experiment, the components flow into a mass spectrometer where they are ionized and their masses are measured. This highly sensitive technique allows the detection and determination of the structure of molecules in a complex mixture. The acquisition strengthens the research infrastructure at the university and regional area. The instrument broadens participation by involving a diverse group of students in research and training using this modern analytical technique. Because the investigator team includes researchers from three HBCUs: Voorhees, Claflin and South Carolina State University, there is a positive effect on undergraduate student researcher.  These institutions have populations that are more than 95% African American and more than 60% female. By using the popular communication/social media tools, as well as the publication in journals and conferences, the impact of the project reaches broader audiences and communities.

This mass spectrometer enhances research and education at all levels. It impacts research investigations of arsenic speciation in sulfidic environments and in evaluating the products of the reaction. The mass spectrometer is also used in studies of the interference mechanisms and antimetabolic effects of natural phytochemicals (Amygdalin) that might be useful to understand cancerous processes. The instrument also serves researchers designing and selecting porous materials for lithium recovery from the environment.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

por.por_cntn:
The overall goal of the project MRI was to acquire an ion-chromatograph mass spectrometer (IC-MS) for research and education at three minority serving institutions, including Voorhees College, South Carolina State University, and Claflin University.  This instrument has been used as an integral part of faculty research and research training as well as students education in environmental science, biology, and chemistry.

In addition, the educational goals of the project was to provide hands-on research experiences in environmental and analytical chemistry for undergraduate students and therefore facilitating the growth of the recently established Environmental Science program at Voorhees College.

Due to the pandemic of Covid-19, students have been taking virtual classes for more than one year since March 2019. The research time has been greatly impacted. The following activities were carried out.

With the instrument, we were able to investigate the speciation analysis of arsenic and thioarsenic species. These species are present in environments with high sulfide concentrations, such as a typical construction and demolition debris landfill, where arsenic containing waste are not uncommon. Compared to typical methods based on HPLC which uses organic solvents, IC methods have shown more efficient separation of the arsenic and thioarsenic species with very little organic solvents (for MS analysis). Mass spectrometry (MS) analysis was performed by both direct infusion into the mass spectrometry and connecting the IC and mass spectrometry, which were able to detect the arsenic species.

The analysis of three polar pesticides has been conducted on the IC-MS. The conditions of the IC and MS for analyzing pesticides standards were explored. The IC-MS instrument will be used to investigate polar pesticides in food in the future.

The project has contributed greatly and will continue contributing to the enrichment of undergraduate students research training at Voorhees College. There were two minority undergraduate students that participated the project. These students have received training on multiple skills (such as quantitative calculations related to solutions and concentrations, chromatography principles, and etc.) and gained hands-on research experience. One conference paper has been submitted to and accepted by national research conference.  One African-American high school senior student was recently involved in the polar pesticides analysis project and has been receiving training on the principles of chromatography and mass spectrometry.

 The project has facilitated partially the establishment of a dedicated Water Analysis and Environmental Chemistry Lab, which will greatly assist the education and research for undergraduate students of related majors at Voorhees College. The project has also facilitated the PI’s collaboration with the faculty members from regional peer institutions (Claflin University and South Carolina State University).

 


Last Modified: 11/28/2021
Modified by: Jianye Zhang
